intro: Amyema bifurcata var. eburna, commonly known as the silver-leafed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees. It is native to parts of Australia and is characterized by its pale, waxy leaves that give it a distinctive silvery appearance. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers followed by red berries that are toxic to humans and animals. It plays a role in the ecosystem by providing food for certain birds and insects. Its parasitic nature means it draws moisture and nutrients from its host, which can affect the health of the host tree over time.
